awd_titl_txt: Understanding Thermal Transport through van der Waals Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
van der Waals (vdW) crystals demonstrate many novel and desirable properties such as highly anisotropic electrical and thermal transport capabilities along different directions.  It has been projected that these materials could revolutionize flexible electronic devices, photovoltaic energy converters, and biomedical devices.  However, a thorough understanding of their electrical and thermal properties has to be achieved first.  This project explores how different factors influence thermal transport through various vdW nanowires.  Systematic studies will be conducted to understand how energy carriers interact with each other and how thermal properties of these nanowires vary as the wire size changes, which will provide new insights into tuning the materials properties for novel devices with improved performance. 

Thermal properties of vdW crystals are extremely important for the proper function of vdW materials-based devices; however, the understanding of thermal transport mechanisms in vdW crystals is far from complete.  This project measures electron and phonon transport through individual quasi-one-dimensional vdW nanowires to provide insights into fundamental questions including how to correctly construct phonon dispersion for vdW crystals, what is the relation between dimensionality transition and the relative strength of intra-chain/inter-chain bonding, and how different phonon scattering mechanisms, especially electron-phonon coupling, affect thermal transport in vdW materials.  Three different kinds of vdW crystals, Ta2Pd3Se8, NbSe3, and TaSe3, which represent a wide spectrum of vdW interaction strength and electrical properties, is examined to dissect the effects of these parameters.  The project generates the urgently-needed knowledge of thermal transport in vdW materials that is critical for various applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this project include (1) the first experimental observation of the divergent thermal conductivity of van der Waals (vdW) crystal NbSe3 nanowires, which are composed of covalently-bonded atomic chains assembled together via weak inter-chain vdW interactions, (2) the observation of distinct signatures of electron-phonon (e-ph) interactions in the lattice thermal conductivity of NbSe3 nanowires upon charge density wave phase transition, and (3) various phenomena induced by electron-phonon-photon coupling inside low-dimensional vdW crystals and at their junctions. These discoveries provide new insights into the transport of charge and energy carriers in quasi-one-dimensional (quasi-1D) vdW crystal nanowires, a new class of materials with promising transport properties for different applications. With the partial support of this project, seven graduate students got trained to conduct interdisciplinary research. Five of the seven graduate students have successfully completed their Ph.D. programs with four of them joining STEM work force and one pursuing a J.D. degree with the goal of practicing patent law.

The most significant discovery of this project is the superdiffusive thermal transport in ultra-thin NbSe3 nanowires. It has been well accepted that at large scales, energy transport in solids is due to diffusion, or random walk of energy carriers. At room temperature, size effect only exists for structures of less than 10 microns, in which energy carriers could ballistically move from one side to the other without being scattered. However, one issue that has been puzzling the scientific community is the divergent thermal conductivity of 1D lattices. In 1955, Fermi, Pasta, Ulam, and Tsingou (FPUT) published their discovery that an excited vibration mode in 1D lattices does not thermalize, even under nonlinear interatomic interactions, which is widely known as the FPUT paradox. A direct consequence of the FPUT paradox is that the thermal conductivity of single atomic chains becomes divergent with the chain length, which has been widely studied theoretically and numerically because of its important implications in fundamental understanding of heat conduction. It has been predicted that the thermal conductivity of 1D lattices follows a 1/3 power law with the chain length. Prior to our study supported by this project, the concept remained purely theoretical as single atomic chains of sufficient length remain experimentally unattainable. In fact, in a perspective letter written by Livi and Lepri in Nature in 2003, they stated ?Hopefully, in the end the results [divergent thermal conductivity of single atomic chains] will go beyond pure academic interest and suggest new ideas for technological applications.?

In this project, we show experimentally that the thermal conductivity of ultra-thin vdW crystal NbSe3 nanowires (~ 10 nm diameter) diverges with the wire length beyond a record level of > 42.5 ?m following a 1/3 power law. In addition, contrary to the classical size effect, the observed thermal conductivity demonstrates a 25-fold enhancement as the diameter of the nanowires reduces from 26 nm to 6.8 nm, while displaying a normal-superdiffusive transition. This experimental demonstration of superdiffusive transport reveals a possibility of creating a class of vdW crystal-based super heat conductors with thermal conductivity values higher than that of any known materials.

In addition to the superdiffusive transport, studies supported by this project also provide solid experimental evidence of the effect of e-ph interactions on the lattice thermal conductivity. While it has been widely believed that e-ph scattering could have important effect on lattice thermal conductivity, experimental evidence of the e-ph scattering effect has been rare because of the challenge to distinguish this effect from other scattering mechanisms. Taking advantage of the spontaneous condensation of free electrons during charge density wave phase transition, we show that the lattice thermal conductivity demonstrates unique features as the e-ph scattering rate changes with the condensation of free electrons. These data allow for experimental validation of the theoretical e-ph scattering rates.

Overall, the research supported by this project provides significant insights into energy transport through quasi-1D vdW crystal NbSe3 nanowires with previously unavailable experimental evidence for superdiffusive thermal transport, which could lead to divergent thermal conductivity that is promising for a class of vdW-crystal-based super heat conductors.
